data.title: Implement multi-root aware file watcher
data.body:
Plan item: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/28344
Feature request #396 

TODO

- [x] Fix module in built package
- [x] Initialize file watcher with `getWorkspace2`, not `basePath` (bugged after reload, until config change)
- [x] Enable new file watcher when opening in multi-root workspace
- [x] PR to reduce nsfw size https://github.com/Axosoft/nsfw/pull/23
- [x] OSS requests
- [x] Support `files.watcherExcludes`
- [x] Don't want roots that are sub-folders of other roots

Blocked:

- Pull in new version of nsfw

data.title: Autocomplete slowing down after long time
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.13.1
- OS Version: WIndows 8.1 64-bit

This issue has been bugging me since I've started using VS Code, but I've never got around to reporting it.

I tend to not turn off my computer(or turn off programs) for long time and I've noticed that after about a week autocomplete in VS Code starts slowing down and after about 3-5 more days it stops working at all. All it takes to fix it is restart the VS Code, but it looks like some sort of memory leak somewhere.

I didn't notice, however, any memory usage increase over time.

Let me know what can I test to help pinpoint this issue.

data.title: Use .gitattributes to remove user configuration influence

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
⚠️ **Do not** rebase, squash, or omit the merge commit during a merge of this pull request.

This change eliminates the influence of the **core.autocrlf** setting on local checkouts. While it looks like a substantial change, users should see *binary identical content* of the entire workspace, with the exception of the **.gitattributes** file, before (for core.autocrlf=input) and after (for any setting) this change.

* Add a **.gitattributes** file to normalize the line endings for text files in the repository
* Configure the **.gitattributes** file to precisely preserve the current use of LF and CRLF in the repository in local checkouts
* Remove execute bit from non-script files
  * Several .svg files
  * resources/linux/debian/*.template
* Add execute bit to one shell script file which was missing it
  * build/tfs/linux/smoketest.sh

:bulb: It is highly preferable to remove as many `eol=crlf` and `eol=lf` lines from the current **.gitignore** as we are able to. For each such case, Windows users will see the file locally with CRLF line endings and other users will see the file locally with LF line endings, but neither system will ever influence the other. For any case where use of a specific line ending is not required for proper behavior, we can allow this platform-specific use without negative consequences.

data.title: Minimap doesn't take editor.scrollBeyondLastLine into account and scrolls beyond the last line
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.14.0-insider (73015a5e052e6de8ecd60eed2670bea81fad8cac, 2017-06-16T05:13:31.107Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.15063
---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Set "editor.scrollBeyondLastLine": false in settings.
The editors now cannot scroll beyond the last line, as expected.

2. Try to scroll via minimap, the minimap still scrolls beyond the last line, which looks weird and incorrect. The minimap preview shows that we are past the file content, but the actual editor shows that we are not past the last line.

Expected behavior:

Minimap should honor the editor settings w.r.t. scrolling past the last time. If editor cannot scroll past the last line, minimap should do the same. At the very minimum, if this sync is not desired for some reason, minimap settings should be introduced that disables scrolling past the last line, e.g. `editor.minimap.scrollBeyondLastLine`

data.title: Allow theming of overview ruler border
data.body:
- VSCode Version:  1.13.1
- OS Version:  Win 10

Problem:
Currently, theme authors are unable to theme/disable the ruler border.  End users can disable it via `overviewRulerBorder` setting but there is no option to do this on the theme end.  

Feature Request:
Allow the theming of the ruler border (and allow for transparency to disable it if need be).

data.title: Custom fonts/width for the sidebar / file-listing
data.body:
The current mechanism for changing the size of the sidebar and its fonts relative to the editor fonts (with the "zoom" property etc) is kludgy.

Please offer a way to set specific font sizes for the sidebar elements (e.g. the file listings, search results, etc).

data.title: Show search results in a page like Sublime Text
data.body:
Using the sidebar tab for search does not provide enough width or contextual information for each match.

It would be nice to offer search results inside a regular VS Code Tab with larger context (lines above and below the result), the way Sublime Text 3 does it.

Bonus points for improving upon Sublime Text's results listing too, e.g. by adding a "refresh/search again" button on the tab with the results.

data.title: A StackFrame.hint 'subtle' is ignored if source attribute is missing
data.body:
VS Code Insider 1.14

Setting `StackFrame.hint` to `subtle` has no effect if the stackframe has a falsy `source` attribute.  

The `hint` is a pure **presentation hint** that should not be coupled with any other attribute.

data.title: Source.hint 'deemphasized' disables certain functionality
data.body:
VS Code Insider 1.14

When setting the `hint` attribute of a Source object to `deemphasized` it is no longer possible to open a StackFrame that uses a `sourceReference` based Source. But a `path` based Source with a `deemphasized` hint still opens fine.

A `hint` on a Source is a pure **presentation style** and should not result in any different behaviour. So there should be no code in VS Code that depends on the value of the `hint` attribute other than rendering code.

data.title: Go to definition of an angular component's templateUrl or styleUrl
data.body:
Hi, I'm not sure if this would be a feature request or just an issue in general. I've been using Webstorm for developing angular projects with typescript and I wanted to make the change to VS Code. There is one key feature that doesn't seem to be working or to be there at all in VS Code, which is the easy go-to-definition of a template file (html) or style file (css). When I'm editing a component in Webstorm, I can Ctrl + Click on the templateUrl's relative path and it opens the file right away.

In VS Code, the go-to-definition on a templateUrl gives me a "No definition found for 'component'". Is it a feature lacking, or just a bug?

Thank you. 
![vscodegotodefinition](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1496661/27254566-c29f0658-5358-11e7-92ae-863863776944.jpg)


- VSCode Version: Code 1.13.1 (379d2efb5539b09112c793d3d9a413017d736f89, 2017-06-14T18:21:47.485Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14393
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|vscode-angular2-files|alexiv|1.3.8|
|vscode-eslint|dbaeumer|1.2.11|
|python|donjayamanne|0.6.5|
|tslint|eg2|0.15.0|
|beautify|HookyQR|1.1.1|
|debugger-for-chrome|msjsdiag|3.1.4|
|language-vscode-javascript-angular2|nwallace|0.0.11|
|autoimport|steoates|1.2.2|;


---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Creating a new empty angular project with the CLI
2. Opening any component's Typescript file
3. Selecting the template or style Url and pressing F12 (or right-clicking 'Go to Definition')

data.title: Commited changes stays in diff editor
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.13.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 Version 1607

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Edit file (like `a.txt`)
2. Open Source Control tab, click modified file (`a.txt`) to open diff editor, write commit message and commit
3. Back to Explorer tab, modify `a.txt` again
4. See modified file(`a.txt`) again, the last time commited change stays in the diff editor

It seems I must close the diff editor manually and reopen it to solve the problem.

![vscode](https://github.com/clumsyme/blogs/blob/master/imgs/vscode.gif?raw=true)

data.title: Toolbar like the one in Visual Studio for most used commands
data.body:
I know, the spirit behind VS Code is to be an editor more than an IDE, and what makes different one of the other is mostly the tool bar. Other products like Atom and Sublime use the command bar for calling commands in the app, however, the convenience of having a customizable toolbar where you can add and remove buttons for the commands you use the most is enormous and helps productivity. I know many developers will not like this, others will love it (like me), you could make it optional (like the minimap was before) maybe include it as a plugin to see what the acceptance rate is among developers.  I would certainly love it, and I think that many others coming from IDEs like Eclipse and VS will love it.

![captura de pantalla 2017-06-18 a la s 08 35 29](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3942218/27261066-25d3e984-5401-11e7-997a-3e9887b2b3b0.png)
(something like this but where you can assign commands to buttons). Even using some generic icon if there is none available for the command would be great. Just having the ability to have a favorite command (indent this file using 4 spaces, for example) handy in that way would be awesome.

data.title: Open windows with different themes
data.body:
Sometimes as a developer (many times as a matter of fact) I need to have multiple windows open, which makes it worse, is the fact that most of the time these windows contain projects written in the same language (Ionic / Angular in my particular case), so all of the projects look mostly the same when you look at the explorer pane. So, basically the only clue I have to know which project is open in the current window, is to look at the folder name in the top of the Explorer pane, --- at least for me, and I bet that for many developers, this is counterintuitive and distracting, it is not the product's fault, VS Code is by far the very best product of its kind in the market (in my opinion way better than the bulky full Visual Studio suite), however, having different windows with different colors, would allow me to work seamlessly with many projects in mac and linux using virtual desktops, which would be the ideal workflow for me.

I have seen that having multiple windows open and installing a new theme in one window, has the side effect that sometimes the theme is not automatically updated in the other windows, this is obviously not intended, but is the say in which until now I have had to tackle this little inconvenience of not having this feature out of the box.

I would love you even more guys if you could implement something like this.

(Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these)
- VSCode Version: May 2017
- OS Version: Mac OS X Sierra

Steps to Reproduce:

1. 
2.

data.title: Pin folders
data.body:
In a large project finding folders can be a pain.  If could pin folders so they appear at the top of the folder listing or in a pinned folder section that would make finding them much faster.

For example, I am working on a branch writing a Crafting widget.  It's a big project so I keep coming back to it and have to find the folder buried deep inside the folder structure of the main project. would be so much more convenient if it was pinned somewhere.

An extension of this feature would be to be able to limit a search to the pinned folder or folders.

Steps to Reproduce:

2. Select `npm: run test`

Instead of getting `npm` output I get:

    '"npm run test"' is not recognized as an internal or external command, operable program or batch file.

Both `npm` and `node` are in my path. I've tried putting `npm` in both my user path and system path and neither worked. If I open an integrated terminal, I can run `npm run test` as expected.

data.title: TS Intellisense hints for parameter defaults?
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.13.0 (376c52b955428d205459bea6619fc161fc8faacf, 2017-06-08T16:41:25.571Z)
- OS Version: Linux x64 4.10.8-100.fc24.x86_64
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|EditorConfig|EditorConfig|0.9.3|
|sort-lines|Tyriar|1.3.0|
|npm-intellisense|christian-kohler|1.3.0|
|vscode-eslint|dbaeumer|1.2.11|
|python|donjayamanne|0.6.5|
|pgsql|doublefint|0.0.8|
|vscode-npm-script|eg2|0.2.0|
|vue|jcbuisson|0.1.5|
|VBScript|luggage66|0.0.1|
|csharp|ms-vscode|1.10.0|
|debugger-for-chrome|msjsdiag|3.1.4|
|addDocComments|stevencl|0.0.8|
|better-align|wwm|1.1.5|;

---

**Expected:**

VS Code shows default values in parameter hints.

---

**Actual:**

VS Code shows this instead:

![download](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5995080/27250362-82663bb6-5325-11e7-8feb-a4183a3ce910.png)

---

Steps to Reproduce


1. Paste example code into TS file.

```js
    /**
     * Get the hash of the last git commit from the log.
     * 
     * @param {number} [length=7] Optionally cut the hash down to this length.
     */
    static getLastCommit(length : number = 7) : string {
        length = Math.min(32, Math.max(7, length));

        return execSync('git log -n 1 --pretty=format:"%H"', {
            cwd: Path.resolve(__dirname, '..'),
            encoding: 'utf8'
        }).substr(0, length);
    }
```

data.title: Linkifier causes window to hang on long lines
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.13.1 (379d2efb5539b09112c793d3d9a413017d736f89, 2017-06-14T18:18:03.540Z)
- OS Version: Linux x64 4.4.0-79-generic (Elementary OS 0.2 Loki/Ubuntu 16.04)
- Extensions: <bug appears with --disable-extensions>
---

So, I ran the command pictured below, which was supposed to print a whole bunch of lines, but because I'm an idiot it printed all the items on one line with a whole lot of literal '\n's between them:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6175424/27249722-f7241eb4-52d0-11e7-9197-a056df4933bc.png)

However, printing said lines caused VS Code to completely lock up, and I had to kill it.  After some testing, I discovered the following in the CPU profiler:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6175424/27249748-65c2c406-52d1-11e7-87c7-f8f90848c124.png)

These are the results after running the profiler for about 10 seconds while VS Code was frozen.  The first line reveals something interesting:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6175424/27249779-01c89984-52d2-11e7-9021-463f0fb903cd.png)

It appears that Linkifier is using a backtracking regular expression to detect links on a single line of the terminal, which, for a line as long as the one I printed, causes the entire window to freeze for several minutes.
